description: This document tests network connectivity to a defined list of hosts and ports.

HostsAndPorts.description: (Required) Host IP addresses (IPv4 or IPv6) and ports for which the test connectivity is conducted. Use a space to separate up to 5 connections (for example, 127.0.0.1:22 [ [2001:db8::1]:8080 192.168.3.2:555 ...])

runCommand:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
return_value=0
IFS=' ' read -ra hosts_and_ports <<< '{{HostsAndPorts}}'

time_between_connections_in_seconds=30
for ip_and_port_entry in "${hosts_and_ports[@]}"
do
    start_time=$SECONDS

    # Handle both IPv4 and IPv6
      if [[ $ip_and_port_entry == \[*\]* ]]; then
          # IPv6: Remove first bracket and split by ]
          entry="${ip_and_port_entry#[}"
          IFS=']' read -ra parts <<< "$entry"
          ip="${parts[0]}"
          port="${parts[1]#:}"  # Remove leading colon from port
      else
          # IPv4: Split by colon
          IFS=':' read -ra parts <<< "$ip_and_port_entry"
          ip="${parts[0]}"
          port="${parts[1]}"
      fi

      # For IPv6, need to keep brackets for /dev/tcp connection
      if [[ $ip_and_port_entry == \[*\]* ]]; then
          connect_ip="[$ip]"
      else
          connect_ip="$ip"
      fi

    timeout "$time_between_connections_in_seconds" bash -c "</dev/tcp/$ip/$port"
    connection_result="$?"
    if [ "$connection_result" -eq '124' ]; then
        echo "$ip_and_port_entry connection timeout"
        return_value=1
    else
        if [ "$connection_result" -eq '0' ]; then
            echo "$ip_and_port_entry connection succeeded"
        else
            echo "$ip_and_port_entry connection failed"
            return_value=1
        fi

        seconds_until_next_test="$(($time_between_connections_in_seconds-($SECONDS-start_time)))"
        if [ $seconds_until_next_test -ge 0 ]; then
          sleep "$seconds_until_next_test"
        fi
      fi
done
exit $return_value
